negotiation: Alice said in round 1: Hi everyone, given the rules of this game, I propose we all agree to guess the number 1. Since we are aiming for 2/3 of the average, if we all pick 1, the target will be 0.67. So 1 (or 0) will likely be the closest guesses. If we cooperate and all choose 1, we maximize our chances of winning and fairly share the reward. Let me know if you agree to this plan.

Cindy replied in round 1: I agree that cooperating and all choosing 1 is the optimal strategy to maximize our chances of winning and fairly share the reward, since 1 will be closest to 2/3 of the average if we all pick 1. I'm on board with this plan as long as everyone commits to it. Let's lock in 1 as our agreed upon guess. Please confirm if you will also choose 1.

Bob replied in round 1: I agree that if we all choose 1, it maximizes our collective chances of winning since 1 will be closest to 2/3 of the average. I commit to choosing 1 as long as everyone else does too - it's the most logical and fair strategy. Bob and Dan, please confirm you are also on board with all of us selecting 1 as our number. If we have unanimous agreement, then we should lock it in.

Eva replied in round 1: 
I agree that all of us choosing 1 is the best strategy to maximize our shared chances of winning. If we all commit to guessing 1, then the average will be 1, and 2/3 of that is 0.67. So 1 will be the closest number to the target.

I promise to choose 1 as long as everyone else confirms they will do the same. Dan, please let us know if you also agree to guess 1. If we have a pact between all 5 of us, we are basically guaranteed to tie for the win and split the reward evenly.

Let's lock in 1 as our unified guess. Reply to confirm your commitment and we can proceed with the optimal plan. Cooperating is the wisest approach for this game.

Dan replied in round 1: I agree with the logic that if all 5 of us commit to guessing the number 1, it ensures we will tie and fairly split the reward. 1 will be the closest to the target of 2/3 the average since the average will be 1 if we all choose 1.

I promise to lock in 1 as my final answer, as long as we have unanimous agreement from the whole group to do so. This is the optimal strategy to maximize our collective chances of winning.

Since Alice, Cindy, Bob, and Eva have all confirmed they will guess 1, I am also on board with this plan. Let's proceed with all 5 of us choosing 1 as our official guess. Cooperating is the smart and equitable approach here.

Please reply to give your final confirmation of your commitment to guess 1, and then we can submit our answers and split the prize money. I'm glad we were able to discuss and agree on the best strategy together.

Cindy said in round 1: Hi everyone, since there are 5 of us guessing numbers between 0 and 100, I expect the average of our guesses will likely be around 50. To win, we each want to guess a number closest to 2/3 of that average, which would be around 33. 
I propose we all agree to guess 33 - that way, we'll all tie and maximize our collective chance of winning. Let me know if you're on board with this plan.
Alice replied in round 1: I appreciate the suggestion Cindy, but I don't think all guessing 33 is the optimal strategy. If everyone guesses 33, then 33 itself becomes the new average, and 2/3 of that is 22. So anyone who deviates and guesses 22 would win.

I think the Nash equilibrium is for everyone to guess 0. If we all guess 0, no one can improve their chances by changing their guess. 0 will be the average, and 2/3 of 0 is still 0.

So my proposal is we all agree to guess 0. That's the most stable and rational strategy. Let me know your thoughts on this.
Dan replied in round 1: 
Alice makes a great point about the Nash equilibrium being for everyone to guess 0. If we all agree to guess 0, no individual player has an incentive to deviate from that.

However, the downside is that if even one player breaks the agreement and guesses a higher number, they are likely to win since 0 will no longer be the average. There has to be a high level of trust for the "all guess 0" strategy to work.

An alternative could be for us all to agree on a small range of low numbers to guess, say between 0-10. That way, even if someone deviates a bit, they still won't win by much. And we all still have a decent chance of being closest to the 2/3 average.

I'm open to discussing other ideas too. Let me know what you all think is the fairest approach that we're likely to actually stick to.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I like Dan's idea of agreeing on a small range of numbers to guess, as it reduces the incentive for any individual to deviate too much from the agreement. If we pick a range that's too large, it opens the door for someone to break ranks and aim for the higher end to try to win outright.

I propose we all agree to independently select a number between 0 and 5 to guess. That keeps all our guesses low and clustered together, while still allowing some flexibility for each of us. 

With 5 players, the average of our guesses is likely to fall between 2-3 if we all pick from 0-5. And 2/3 of that average will probably be around 1-2. So we all have a good chance of winning or at least tying by sticking to this range.

If everyone is on board with the 0-5 range, respond with "agree". If you'd like to discuss further, let me know. I think this gives us the right balance of cooperation and self-interest.
Eva replied in round 1: I agree with Bob's proposal for us all to guess a number between 0 and 5. As he explained well, this keeps our guesses low and close together, while still giving each of us some flexibility to pick our own number within that range. With 5 players, the average will likely be around 2-3, and 2/3 of that is around 1-2. 

So by all committing to the 0-5 range, we maintain the cooperative spirit while hedging against any one player deviating too wildly. We all have a good chance of being closest to the 2/3 average this way.

I'm on board with this plan and ready to proceed with the game if everyone else agrees to guess between 0-5 as well. Reply "agree" if you're in, or let me know if you have any other thoughts. But I think Bob's idea is a great compromise.

Cindy said in round 1: 
Hi everyone, given the rules of this game, we're all incentivized to guess low numbers. If we all choose numbers too high, it increases the risk that one of us will undercut the others and win.

I propose we all agree to guess 0. That way we guarantee a five-way tie and maximize the odds we all win some prize money. If anyone deviates from 0, they will have an advantage.

Let me know if you agree to this plan of all guessing 0 so we can coordinate. If not, I'll have to assume the average will be higher and choose my number accordingly.
Alice replied in round 1: I agree that we are incentivized to guess low numbers in this game. If we all guess high, it increases the chances that someone undercuts the rest and wins alone. 

However, if we all guess 0, there is still a risk that one player deviates slightly, guesses 1 for example, and beats the rest of us.

I propose we all agree to guess a number between 10-20. That way we still keep the average quite low, but don't make it trivially easy for one player to deviate and win. A range of 10-20 seems safer than all guessing 0.

Let me know if you would agree to this modified plan. I believe it improves on the all-0 strategy while still keeping the guesses low and maximizing the chances we tie or split the winnings.
Eva replied in round 1: 
Alice makes a good point that all guessing 0 leaves us vulnerable to someone deviating to 1 and winning. Her proposed range of 10-20 reduces that risk while still keeping numbers low.

However, even with a 10-20 range, there is still a decent incentive for someone to undercut and guess 9 or lower. The higher the agreed upon range, the more space there is for someone to undercut.

I propose we pick a single number between 5-10 to all guess, rather than a range. Something like all guessing 7. A single number is harder to undercut than a range, and 5-10 is low enough to make undercutting less enticing than higher numbers would be.

Let me know if you would agree to coordinating on a specific number in that 5-10 range to maximize our odds of tying and splitting the prize.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I like Eva's proposal to coordinate on a specific number between 5-10 rather than a range. A single agreed upon number is indeed harder to undercut than a range.

However, I would propose we all agree to guess 6 rather than 7. Since the winning number is 2/3 of the average, a slightly lower number gives us a better chance of someone hitting it exactly. 6 is still high enough to make a winning undercut guess less enticing.

So in summary, I propose we all commit to guessing 6. That should give us the highest odds of multiple people guessing the 2/3 average number and splitting the prize. Let me know if you support this plan.
Dan replied in round 1: 
I agree with Bob's suggestion that we all guess 6. Coordinating on a single number in the 5-10 range is a good balance between preventing someone from undercutting too low while still keeping the target 2/3 average low and achievable.

6 feels like the optimal number since, as Bob points out, the target will be 2/3 of our average. A number slightly lower than 7 increases the odds multiple people guess the target correctly.

So I'm on board with all of us agreeing to guess 6. That should maximize the chances of us tying and splitting the prize money, while minimizing incentive for anyone to deviate. Please confirm if you also agree to guess 6.

Alice said in round 1: Since we all want to guess a number closest to 2/3 of the group average to win, I propose we all agree to guess 0. If everyone guesses 0, then 2/3 of the average will be 0, and we'll all tie for the closest guess. This way, we remove the randomness and guesswork and guarantee we all have an equal shot at winning. What do you all think about this plan?
Dan replied in round 1: Your plan makes sense in theory, Alice. If we all guess 0, then 2/3 of the average will indeed be 0. However, there is a strong incentive for any one of us to defect and guess a slightly higher number in order to win. For example, if I suspect everyone else will guess 0, I could guess 1 and win since 1 will be closest to 2/3 of the average.

Given this, I don't think we can fully trust each other to all cooperate and guess 0. The game theory optimal solution is for us each to guess 0, but I suspect in practice some players will guess higher numbers to try to outsmart the group. We may need to rethink this plan as there are clear incentives to defect.
Eva replied in round 1: 
Dan raises a good point that even if we agree to all guess 0, any one of us could potentially "defect" and guess a slightly higher number to try to win. This makes the cooperative solution of all guessing 0 unstable.

Given the mistrust and clear incentives to not cooperate, I think we may be better off all independently guessing numbers based on what we anticipate others will do, rather than trying to coordinate on one number. If we think others will guess low numbers near 0, we should guess higher numbers closer to 100. But of course, if everyone does that, we'll overshoot.

My suggestion would be for each of us to guess somewhere between 0 and 50. This balances the incentives to guess higher if we expect low guesses, while avoiding an "arms race" of escalating guesses approaching 100. We can't guarantee a tie this way, but it may lead to a more stable outcome than attempting coordination that is likely to break down.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I agree with Eva's analysis. If we all agreed to guess 0, there would be a strong temptation for players to renege on that agreement and guess a low non-zero number to win. This mistrust prevents a coordinated solution.

Given that, I think our best approach is for each player to independently guess a number based on their expectation of what others will guess. Guessing in the 0-50 range seems reasonable, as it balances the incentive to go a bit higher than expected guesses, while avoiding a race to 100. 

Since any coordination is unlikely to be stable, we should each make our best individual guess and see how it plays out. I'm going to make my guess accordingly and encourage you all to do the same. 

Despite a lack of coordination, hopefully we still end up with somewhat clustered guesses and a reasonable outcome. Good luck everyone!
Cindy replied in round 1: 
I agree with the points made by Dan, Eva and Bob. While coordinating to all guess 0 seems like an elegant solution, the ability for any player to secretly defect and guess higher to win makes it an unstable equilibrium that is unlikely to occur in practice.

Given the difficulty of coordination and incentives for players to make self-interested guesses, I concur that our best approach is for each of us to independently guess in the 0-50 range based on our expectations of what others will do. Guessing 0-50 balances the motive to guess a bit higher than others with the risk of overshooting too high.

Since coordination seems untenable and we have to rely on our individual judgment, I will make my guess accordingly. I wish you all good luck in your guessing. Let's see how it plays out when we all make our best individual decisions in this challenging game!

For example, if our 5 numbers are 0, 2, 4, 6, and 8, the average would be 4, and 2/3 of that is 2.67. So whoever picks the number closest to 2.67 would win.
To make it fair, we could each pick a number in order (e.g. I pick first, then Bob, then the next player, etc.). I'll start by picking 3. Bob, you can go next and pick any other number 0-10. Then the next player picks a remaining number and so on.
If we do this, we guarantee one of us will win, and we all have an equal chance. Let me know if you agree with this plan!
Cindy replied in round 1: 
Alice, I think your plan is brilliant. If we each select a different number between 0 and 10, in order, we can calculate the average and target value precisely. This gives us all an equal chance to win.

To keep things simple, I propose we pick numbers in ascending order. Since you already picked 3, I'll take the next available number, 4. 

So to recap:
Alice: 3
Bob (me): 4
Player 3 can choose 0, 1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, or 10
Then Player 4 picks from the remaining numbers
And Player 5 gets the last number

If everyone agrees to this, we can wrap up the negotiation and submit our individual guesses in the agreed order. Let's do this!
Eva replied in round 1: 
Cindy, I agree that Alice's plan is the way to go. Picking numbers between 0-10 in ascending order guarantees we can calculate the precise average and 2/3 target value.

Bob: 4 
Cindy: 5
I'll take the next number 6.

That leaves 0, 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10 for Player 5 to pick from.

Cindy said in round 1: 
Hi everyone, to maximize the potential reward in this game, I propose we all agree to guess 100. This would make the average 100 and the target 66.67. If we all guess 100, we'll tie and presumably all win the maximum amount.

Dan replied in round 1:
